Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: A Short, Open-Access 2D MCS Acquisition Program off Washington State
Award.AbstractNarration: The great Tohoku earthquake and tsunami of 2011 has reminded us of the hazards to life and property that attend such events, and of the need for a focused scientific effort to understand both their causes and effects. Cascadia, which extends from northern California to southern British Columbia, will be the site of a future great earthquake that will affect a number of large metropolitan centers, including Seattle and Portland. The Cascadia Initiative is an effort to gain a better understanding of seismicity in the region that includes the deployment of an array of instruments both onshore and offshore. Several ancillary studies are also planned or under way; one such study is a sophisticated 3D (three dimensional) seismic survey to be carried out off the coast of Washington. The suite of 2D seismic profiles that will be acquired by this project will provide essential data for planning and carrying out the 3D survey. The chief broader impact of this study is the very high societal relevance of gaining an improved understanding of the seismic risk in this region.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported acquisition of a grid of open-access 2D seismic reflection profiles from the continental margin offshore Grays Harbor, WA.  The project (known as COAST for Cascadia Open-Access Seismic Transects) was led by Professor Steve Holbrook of the University of Wyoming. Comprehensive reporting of project outcomes will be reported when a one-year no-cost extension of the University of Wyoming grant is complete.  In addition to participating in the planning, permitting and selection of student participants for the cruise and initial interpretation of the open-access data, the Oregon State University group installed seismometers on land to record the offshore shots, thus expanding the volume Earth that was imaged by the experiment and providing a critical link between the new offshore data and previous results obtained from purely land-based experiments.  This particular grant only included funds to acquire the data.  The onshore recordings of the offshore shots have been processed and are currently being modeled and interpreted by Oregon State in conjunction with analysis of a related project to image crustal structure of the central Cascadia subduction zone of Oregon. The data acquired for this project are "open-access," which means that they are available immediately on request to anyone who want them.  


Last Modified: 07/30/2013
Modified by: Anne M Trehu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project supported acquisition of a grid of open-access 2D seismic reflection profiles from the continental margin offshore Grays Harbor, WA. The project (known as COAST for Cascadia Open-Access Seismic Transects) was led by Professor Steve Holbrook of the University of Wyoming. Comprehensive reporting of project outcomes will be reported when a one-year no-cost extension of the University of Wyoming grant is complete. In addition to participating in the planning, permitting and selection of student participants for the cruise and initial interpretation of the open-access data, the Oregon State University group installed seismometers on land to record the offshore shots, thus expanding the volume Earth that was imaged by the experiment and providing a critical link between the new offshore data and previous results obtained from purely land-based experiments. This particular grant only included funds to acquire the data. The onshore recordings of the offshore shots have been processed and are currently being modeled and interpreted by Oregon State in conjunction with analysis of a related project to image crustal structure of the central Cascadia subduction zone of Oregon. The data acquired for this project are "open-access," which means that they are available immediately on request to anyone who want them. Last Modified: 07/30/2013 Submitted by: Anne M Trehu
